cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
Helen Keller, who became deaf and blind at a young age due to an illness, faced significant challenges in communication. Her breakthrough in learning to communicate came when she met Anne Sullivan, who became her teacher and lifelong companion. Sullivan employed various methods, including finger-spelling words into Keller's hand, to help her understand language and express herself. This transformative relationship was crucial in Keller's development and education.

Answer: Anne Sullivan.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['A message of optimism, of hope, of good cheer, and of loving service was brought to Menomonie Saturday—a message that will linger long with those fortunate enough to have received it. This message came with the visit of Helen Keller and her teacher, Mrs. John Macy, and both had a hand in imparting it Saturday evening to a splendid audience that filled The Memorial. The wonderful girl who has so brilliantly triumphed over the triple afflictions of blindness, dumbness and deafness, gave a talk with her own lips on "Happiness," and it will be remembered always as a piece of inspired teaching by those who heard it.\n', 'Sullivan arrived at Keller\'s house on March 5, 1887, a day Keller would forever remember as "my soul\'s birthday." Sullivan immediately began to teach Helen to communicate by spelling words into her hand, beginning with "d-o-l-l" for the doll that she had brought Keller as a present. Keller was frustrated, at first, because she did not understand that every object had a word uniquely identifying it. In fact, when Sullivan was trying to teach Keller the word for "mug", Keller became so frustrated she broke the mug. But soon she began imitating Sullivan’s hand gestures. “I did not know that I was spelling a word or even that words existed,” Keller remembered. “I was simply making my fingers go in monkey-like imitation.” \n', 'Determined to communicate with others as conventionally as possible, Keller learned to speak and spent much of her life giving speeches and lectures on aspects of her life. She learned to "hear" people\'s speech by reading their lips with her hands—her sense of touch had heightened. She became proficient at using braille and reading sign language with her hands as well. Shortly before World War I, with the assistance of the Zoellner Quartet, she determined that by placing her fingertips on a resonant tabletop she could experience music played close by.\n', "Sullivan's curriculum involved a strict schedule with constant introduction of new vocabulary words; however, Sullivan quickly changed her teachings after seeing they did not suit Keller. Instead, she began to teach her vocabulary based on her own interests, by spelling each word out into Keller's palm; within six months this method proved to be working, as Keller had learned 575 words, some multiplication tables, and the Braille system. Sullivan strongly encouraged Helen's parents to send her to the Perkins School, where she could have an appropriate education. Once they agreed to this, Sullivan took Keller to Boston in 1888 and stayed with her there. Sullivan continued to teach her bright protégée, who soon became famous for her remarkable progress. With the help of Anagnos, Keller became a public symbol for the school, helping to increase its funding and donations and making it the most famous and sought-after school for the blind in the country. However, an accusation of plagiarism against Keller greatly upset Sullivan: She left and never returned, but did remain influential to the school. Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller and continued to assist in her education, which ultimately included a degree from Radcliffe College.\n", 'Named after Helen Adams Keller (1880–1968), an American author and educator of the blind. From infancy, Keller was without power of speech and was also deaf and blind. With the inestimable assistance of Anne M. Sullivan, Keller learnt to read and to write by Braille; to use a typewriter; and even to speak, and eventually mastered five languages. Upon graduating with honours from Radeliffe, she began to lecture extensively on the education of the blind; and has received many honours for achievement. Helen Keller greatly furthered the work of the "Foundation of the Blind".\n', 'BULLET::::- In 1925 Helen Keller, through her long-time teacher Anne Sullivan, gave a talk to an audience of 200 at Old Mill School.\n', 'Marcelle Kellermann became a teacher of modern languages in Leeds and at Bingley College of Education in Yorkshire. Her articles on the subject of language teaching included "Two experiments on language teaching in primary schools in Leeds", published by the Nuffield Foundation in 1964. Her monograph in Pergamon Press\'s Language Teaching Methodology series, "The Forgotten Third Skill: Reading a Foreign Language", was published in 1981. She was said to have "pioneered the teaching of French to primary school children".\n', 'According to Anne Sullivan, Helen Keller had developed over sixty home signs long before she was taught to communicate through finger spelling.\n', 'Helen Keller School\n', 'In 1890, Fuller applied the methods she learned and developed from Bell in giving the first speech lessons to Helen Keller.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question "Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?" we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. The key points that provide background and context include:

1. **Anne Sullivan's Role**: 
   - Several passages explicitly mention Anne Sullivan as the teacher who played a crucial role in teaching Helen Keller to communicate. For example, one passage states, "Sullivan arrived at Keller's house on March 5, 1887... immediately began to teach Helen to communicate by spelling words into her hand." This indicates that Sullivan was not only Keller's teacher but also a pivotal figure in her life, marking the beginning of Keller's journey to communication.

2. **Teaching Methodology**: 
   - The passages describe Sullivan's innovative teaching methods, such as spelling words into Keller's hand. This method was essential in helping Keller understand that objects have names, which was a breakthrough for her. The passage mentions Keller's initial frustration and how she began to imitate Sullivan’s gestures, highlighting the challenges and breakthroughs in their communication process.

3. **Progress and Achievements**: 
   - Another passage notes that within six months of Sullivan's teaching, Keller learned 575 words and some multiplication tables. This illustrates the effectiveness of Sullivan's teaching methods and Keller's remarkable progress, which is significant in understanding the impact of Sullivan's role in Keller's education.

4. **Long-term Relationship**: 
   - The passages also indicate that Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller throughout her education, even after leaving the Perkins School. This long-term relationship emphasizes the importance of emotional and social support in Keller's learning process.

5. **Keller's Broader Impact**: 
   - The passages mention that Keller became a public symbol for the education of the blind and helped increase funding for the Perkins School. This context shows that Keller's achievements were not just personal but had a wider societal impact, which was made possible through Sullivan's guidance.

6. **Additional Context on Keller's Abilities**: 
   - The passages also highlight Keller's eventual mastery of multiple languages and her ability to communicate through various means, including braille and lip-reading. This information is crucial as it illustrates the extent of Keller's communication skills, which were developed under Sullivan's tutelage.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

- **Understanding the Teacher-Student Dynamic**: The extracted content emphasizes the transformative relationship between Keller and Sullivan. It showcases how Sullivan's methods were tailored to Keller's unique needs, which is vital in understanding effective teaching strategies for individuals with disabilities.

- **Highlighting Challenges and Breakthroughs**: The passages reflect the challenges Keller faced in her early learning stages and how Sullivan's persistence and adaptability led to breakthroughs. This narrative is important for understanding the complexities of teaching communication to someone with multiple disabilities.

- **Significance of Emotional Support**: The long-term companionship between Keller and Sullivan underscores the importance of emotional and psychological support in education, particularly for students with disabilities. This aspect is often overlooked but is critical for fostering a conducive learning environment.

- **Broader Implications**: Keller's eventual success and her role as an advocate for the blind highlight the societal implications of effective education. This context is essential for understanding the broader impact of Sullivan's teaching beyond just Keller's personal achievements.

In summary, the extracted content provides a comprehensive understanding of the pivotal role Anne Sullivan played in teaching Helen Keller to communicate, the methods used, the challenges faced, and the broader implications of their relationship. This background knowledge is crucial for answering the original question accurately and with depth.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question "Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?" we can build upon the existing reasoning by integrating additional context and details from the retrieved knowledge.

1. **Anne Sullivan's Role**: 
   - Anne Sullivan is widely recognized as the teacher who profoundly impacted Helen Keller's ability to communicate. She began teaching Keller on March 5, 1887, a date Keller referred to as "my soul's birthday." This moment marked the beginning of Keller's journey toward understanding language and communication.

2. **Innovative Teaching Methods**: 
   - Sullivan employed a unique method of finger-spelling words into Keller's hand, which was crucial for Keller's comprehension of language. This tactile approach helped Keller associate words with objects, a fundamental breakthrough that allowed her to begin expressing herself. The initial frustration Keller experienced illustrates the challenges faced by both teacher and student, emphasizing the need for patience and adaptability in teaching methods.

3. **Significant Progress**: 
   - Within six months of Sullivan's instruction, Keller had learned an impressive 575 words and basic multiplication, showcasing the effectiveness of Sullivan's tailored teaching strategies. This rapid progress highlights the potential for individuals with disabilities to achieve remarkable milestones when provided with appropriate educational support.

4. **Long-term Relationship and Support**: 
   - Sullivan's role extended beyond that of a teacher; she became a lifelong companion and advocate for Keller. This enduring relationship underscores the importance of emotional and social support in the educational journey of individuals with disabilities. Sullivan's encouragement and guidance were instrumental in Keller's development and success.

5. **Keller's Broader Impact**: 
   - Keller's achievements, including her advocacy for the blind and her role in increasing funding for the Perkins School, illustrate the societal impact of her education. Sullivan's teaching not only transformed Keller's life but also contributed to broader awareness and support for the education of individuals with disabilities.

6. **Keller's Communication Skills**: 
   - Over time, Keller mastered multiple languages and various forms of communication, including braille and lip-reading. This progression highlights the effectiveness of Sullivan's teaching methods and the potential for individuals with disabilities to develop diverse communication skills.

### Enhanced Summary:
The relationship between Anne Sullivan and Helen Keller was transformative, characterized by innovative teaching methods, significant progress in Keller's communication abilities, and a long-lasting emotional bond. Sullivan's approach tailored to Keller's unique needs allowed her to overcome substantial challenges, ultimately leading to Keller's success as a public figure and advocate for the blind. This context is essential for understanding the profound impact of Sullivan's teaching on Keller's life and the broader implications for education.

### Answer:
Anne Sullivan.

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. Identify points of agreement and disagreement among the experts, and analyze how these differing perspectives contribute to a deeper understanding of the topic. Synthesize the insights from the discussion into a cohesive summary that captures the full range of foundational and advanced knowledge. Highlight how these perspectives expand the understanding of the question.

By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Expert Discussion on Helen Keller's Communication Education**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
"I'd like to start by emphasizing the pivotal role of Anne Sullivan in Helen Keller's education. The passage detailing Sullivan's arrival on March 5, 1887, as Keller's 'soul's birthday' is significant. It marks the beginning of a transformative journey where Sullivan introduced Keller to the concept of communication through finger spelling. This method was revolutionary for Keller, who had previously been isolated due to her disabilities."

**Expert 2: Educational Methods Expert**
"I agree with the importance of Sullivan's methods, but I want to highlight the adaptability of her teaching style. The passage mentions that Sullivan quickly shifted her approach after realizing that her initial curriculum did not suit Keller's needs. This flexibility is crucial in educational contexts, especially when working with students who have unique challenges. By tailoring her lessons to Keller's interests, Sullivan was able to foster a more effective learning environment."

**Expert 3: Communication and Language Development Specialist**
"Building on that point, it's fascinating to note that Keller had already developed over sixty home signs before Sullivan began teaching her finger spelling. This indicates that Keller had an innate desire to communicate, which Sullivan recognized and nurtured. The passage about Keller's frustration with learning new words illustrates the emotional and psychological aspects of communication development. It wasn't just about teaching vocabulary; it was about building a bridge between Keller's world and the world around her."

**Expert 4: Legacy and Impact Scholar**
"Indeed, the emotional aspect is critical. However, we must also consider the broader impact of Keller's education on society. The passage discussing her later achievements, including her graduation from Radcliffe College and her extensive lectures on the education of the blind, shows how Sullivan's teaching laid the groundwork for Keller to become a public figure advocating for the rights of people with disabilities. This legacy is as important as the methods used in her education."

**Expert 5: Historical Figures and Their Influence**
"While we celebrate Sullivan's contributions, we should also acknowledge the role of other educators in Keller's life. For instance, the passage mentioning Fuller providing speech lessons indicates that Keller's education was not solely the work of Sullivan. It was a collaborative effort involving multiple educators who contributed to her development."

**Synthesis of Insights**
The discussion highlights the multifaceted nature of Helen Keller's education and communication development. Anne Sullivan is rightly recognized as a central figure in Keller's life, employing innovative and adaptive teaching methods that catered to Keller's unique needs. However, the conversation also reveals that Keller's communication journey was a collaborative effort, involving other educators and her own innate desire to connect with the world.

The emotional and psychological dimensions of Keller's learning process are crucial, as they underscore the challenges she faced and the resilience she demonstrated. Furthermore, Keller's eventual success and advocacy work illustrate the lasting impact of her education on society's understanding of disabilities.

In summary, the perspectives shared by the experts deepen our understanding of the question by illustrating that Keller's ability to communicate was not solely the result of Sullivan's teaching but a complex interplay of personal determination, innovative educational practices, and the contributions of multiple individuals. This comprehensive view enriches our appreciation of Keller's legacy and the ongoing importance of adaptive education for individuals with disabilities.

**Discussion-enhanced Reasoning Process:**

The discussion surrounding Helen Keller's communication education reveals a nuanced understanding of her journey, emphasizing the pivotal role of Anne Sullivan while also recognizing the contributions of other educators and Keller's own innate abilities. 

1. **Role of Anne Sullivan**: The consensus among experts is that Anne Sullivan was instrumental in teaching Keller to communicate. Her innovative methods, particularly finger-spelling into Keller's hand, opened the door to language for Keller, who had been isolated due to her disabilities. This foundational relationship is often referred to as transformative, marking a significant turning point in Keller's life.

2. **Adaptability of Teaching Methods**: Experts highlighted Sullivan's adaptability in her teaching approach. Initially, her methods did not resonate with Keller, prompting her to modify her curriculum to better suit Keller's interests and needs. This flexibility is crucial in educational contexts, especially for students with unique challenges, and showcases Sullivan's commitment to Keller's learning.

3. **Keller's Pre-existing Communication Skills**: It is noteworthy that Keller had developed over sixty home signs before Sullivan's arrival. This indicates that Keller had a natural inclination towards communication, which Sullivan recognized and nurtured. This aspect emphasizes the importance of understanding a student's background and existing skills when developing an educational plan.

4. **Emotional and Psychological Dimensions**: The emotional challenges Keller faced during her learning process were significant. Her initial frustration with learning new words illustrates the psychological hurdles that accompany communication development. Sullivan's role was not just to teach vocabulary but to help Keller bridge the gap between her world and that of others.

5. **Legacy and Broader Impact**: Keller's education had far-reaching implications beyond her personal achievements. Her eventual success as an advocate for the rights of people with disabilities highlights the societal impact of Sullivan's teaching. Keller's legacy serves as a reminder of the importance of adaptive education and the potential for individuals with disabilities to contribute meaningfully to society.

6. **Collaborative Efforts**: While Sullivan is often credited as Keller's primary teacher, the discussion acknowledges the contributions of other educators, such as Fuller, who provided speech lessons. This collaborative effort underscores that Keller's education was not solely the work of one individual but a collective endeavor that involved multiple influences.

**Conclusion**: The synthesis of these expert insights provides a comprehensive understanding of Helen Keller's communication education. It illustrates that while Anne Sullivan was a central figure in Keller's journey, her ability to communicate was also shaped by her own determination, the contributions of various educators, and the emotional and psychological aspects of her learning experience.

**Answer**: Anne Sullivan taught Helen Keller to communicate, employing innovative methods such as finger-spelling, while also recognizing Keller's pre-existing communication skills and adapting her teaching to suit Keller's needs.

Upon graduating with honours from Radeliffe, she began to lecture extensively on the education of the blind; and has received many honours for achievement. Helen Keller greatly furthered the work of the "Foundation of the Blind".
', 'BULLET::::- In 1925 Helen Keller, through her long-time teacher Anne Sullivan, gave a talk to an audience of 200 at Old Mill School.
', 'Marcelle Kellermann became a teacher of modern languages in Leeds and at Bingley College of Education in Yorkshire. Her articles on the subject of language teaching included "Two experiments on language teaching in primary schools in Leeds", published by the Nuffield Foundation in 1964. Her monograph in Pergamon Press's Language Teaching Methodology series, "The Forgotten Third Skill: Reading a Foreign Language", was published in 1981. She was said to have "pioneered the teaching of French to primary school children".
', 'According to Anne Sullivan, Helen Keller had developed over sixty home signs long before she was taught to communicate through finger spelling.
', 'Helen Keller School
', 'In 1890, Fuller applied the methods she learned and developed from Bell in giving the first speech lessons to Helen Keller.
']

Task Description:

consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To answer the question of which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages. The key points are as follows:

1. **Anne Sullivan's Arrival**: Sullivan arrived at Keller's house on March 5, 1887, which Keller referred to as "my soul's birthday." This marks the beginning of Keller's formal education in communication.

2. **Teaching Method**: Sullivan began teaching Keller to communicate by spelling words into her hand, starting with the word "d-o-l-l" for a doll she had brought. This method involved tactile learning, where Keller would feel the letters being spelled out.

3. **Initial Frustration**: Keller experienced frustration initially because she did not understand that each object had a unique word. This highlights the challenges in the learning process and the importance of patience and adaptation in teaching.

4. **Adaptation of Teaching Methods**: Sullivan adapted her teaching methods based on Keller's interests and needs, which proved effective. Within six months, Keller had learned 575 words and some multiplication tables.

5. **Long-term Influence**: Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller throughout her education, influencing her learning and development even after leaving the Perkins School.

6. **Achievements**: With Sullivan's assistance, Keller learned to read and write in Braille, use a typewriter, and eventually speak. She became proficient in multiple languages and graduated with honors from Radcliffe College.

7. **Recognition of Sullivan's Role**: The passages consistently attribute Keller's communication skills and educational achievements to Anne Sullivan, emphasizing her pivotal role as a teacher.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

The consolidated information enhances the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities in several ways:

- **Understanding Cause and Effect**: The passages illustrate a clear cause-and-effect relationship between Sullivan's teaching methods and Keller's ability to communicate. This helps the model recognize how specific actions (like spelling words into Keller's hand) lead to significant outcomes (Keller learning to communicate).

- **Adaptation and Learning**: The adaptation of teaching methods based on Keller's responses demonstrates the importance of flexibility in education. The model can learn to infer that effective teaching often requires adjustments based on the learner's needs and progress.

- **Longitudinal Influence**: The ongoing relationship between Keller and Sullivan shows how sustained support and mentorship can lead to long-term success. This can help the model understand the importance of continuous guidance in achieving complex goals.

- **Complex Interactions**: The passages highlight the complexities of learning, including emotional responses (frustration) and the gradual development of skills. This complexity can improve the model's ability to reason about multifaceted situations and the various factors that contribute to learning outcomes.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich context for understanding the dynamics of teaching and learning, which can significantly enhance the model's capabilities in causal reasoning and logical inference.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

Helen Keller, who became deaf and blind at a young age due to an illness, faced significant challenges in communication. Her breakthrough in learning to communicate came when she met Anne Sullivan, who became her teacher and lifelong companion. 

1. **Anne Sullivan's Arrival**: Sullivan arrived at Keller's house on March 5, 1887, which Keller referred to as "my soul's birthday." This date marks the beginning of Keller's formal education in communication, indicating the significance of this event in her life.

2. **Teaching Method**: Sullivan employed various methods, including finger-spelling words into Keller's hand. She started with simple words, such as "d-o-l-l" for a doll she had brought. This tactile learning approach was crucial for Keller, who could not hear or see, allowing her to connect physical objects with their corresponding words.

3. **Initial Frustration**: Keller initially experienced frustration because she did not understand that each object had a unique word. This highlights the challenges in the learning process and the importance of patience and adaptation in teaching. It also illustrates the emotional aspects of learning, which can affect motivation and progress.

4. **Adaptation of Teaching Methods**: Sullivan quickly adapted her teaching methods based on Keller's interests and needs. This flexibility proved effective; within six months, Keller had learned 575 words and some multiplication tables. This adaptability is a key factor in successful education, as it allows the teacher to meet the learner's evolving needs.

5. **Long-term Influence**: Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller throughout her education, influencing her learning and development even after leaving the Perkins School. This long-term mentorship underscores the importance of sustained support in achieving educational goals.

6. **Achievements**: With Sullivan's assistance, Keller learned to read and write in Braille, use a typewriter, and eventually speak. She became proficient in multiple languages and graduated with honors from Radcliffe College. These achievements demonstrate the effectiveness of Sullivan's teaching methods and the profound impact of their relationship.

7. **Recognition of Sullivan's Role**: The passages consistently attribute Keller's communication skills and educational achievements to Anne Sullivan, emphasizing her pivotal role as a teacher. This recognition is essential for understanding the dynamics of their relationship and the importance of effective teaching.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

The enhanced reasoning process provides a deeper understanding of the causal relationships involved in Keller's education:

- **Understanding Cause and Effect**: The passages illustrate a clear cause-and-effect relationship between Sullivan's teaching methods and Keller's ability to communicate. This helps the model recognize how specific actions (like spelling words into Keller's hand) lead to significant outcomes (Keller learning to communicate).

- **Adaptation and Learning**: The adaptation of teaching methods based on Keller's responses demonstrates the importance of flexibility in education. The model can learn to infer that effective teaching often requires adjustments based on the learner's needs and progress.

- **Longitudinal Influence**: The ongoing relationship between Keller and Sullivan shows how sustained support and mentorship can lead to long-term success. This can help the model understand the importance of continuous guidance in achieving complex goals.

- **Complex Interactions**: The passages highlight the complexities of learning, including emotional responses (frustration) and the gradual development of skills. This complexity can improve the model's ability to reason about multifaceted situations and the various factors that contribute to learning outcomes.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich context for understanding the dynamics of teaching and learning, which can significantly enhance the model's capabilities in causal reasoning and logical inference.

### Answer:
Anne Sullivan.

Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['A message of optimism, of hope, of good cheer, and of loving service was brought to Menomonie Saturday—a message that will linger long with those fortunate enough to have received it. This message came with the visit of Helen Keller and her teacher, Mrs. John Macy, and both had a hand in imparting it Saturday evening to a splendid audience that filled The Memorial. The wonderful girl who has so brilliantly triumphed over the triple afflictions of blindness, dumbness and deafness, gave a talk with her own lips on "Happiness," and it will be remembered always as a piece of inspired teaching by those who heard it.\n', 'Sullivan arrived at Keller\'s house on March 5, 1887, a day Keller would forever remember as "my soul\'s birthday." Sullivan immediately began to teach Helen to communicate by spelling words into her hand, beginning with "d-o-l-l" for the doll that she had brought Keller as a present. Keller was frustrated, at first, because she did not understand that every object had a word uniquely identifying it. In fact, when Sullivan was trying to teach Keller the word for "mug", Keller became so frustrated she broke the mug. But soon she began imitating Sullivan’s hand gestures. “I did not know that I was spelling a word or even that words existed,” Keller remembered. “I was simply making my fingers go in monkey-like imitation.” \n', 'Determined to communicate with others as conventionally as possible, Keller learned to speak and spent much of her life giving speeches and lectures on aspects of her life. She learned to "hear" people\'s speech by reading their lips with her hands—her sense of touch had heightened. She became proficient at using braille and reading sign language with her hands as well. Shortly before World War I, with the assistance of the Zoellner Quartet, she determined that by placing her fingertips on a resonant tabletop she could experience music played close by.\n', "Sullivan's curriculum involved a strict schedule with constant introduction of new vocabulary words; however, Sullivan quickly changed her teachings after seeing they did not suit Keller. Instead, she began to teach her vocabulary based on her own interests, by spelling each word out into Keller's palm; within six months this method proved to be working, as Keller had learned 575 words, some multiplication tables, and the Braille system. Sullivan strongly encouraged Helen's parents to send her to the Perkins School, where she could have an appropriate education. Once they agreed to this, Sullivan took Keller to Boston in 1888 and stayed with her there. Sullivan continued to teach her bright protégée, who soon became famous for her remarkable progress. With the help of Anagnos, Keller became a public symbol for the school, helping to increase its funding and donations and making it the most famous and sought-after school for the blind in the country. However, an accusation of plagiarism against Keller greatly upset Sullivan: She left and never returned, but did remain influential to the school. Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller and continued to assist in her education, which ultimately included a degree from Radcliffe College.\n", 'Named after Helen Adams Keller (1880–1968), an American author and educator of the blind. From infancy, Keller was without power of speech and was also deaf and blind. With the inestimable assistance of Anne M. Sullivan, Keller learnt to read and to write by Braille; to use a typewriter; and even to speak, and eventually mastered five languages. Upon graduating with honours from Radeliffe, she began to lecture extensively on the education of the blind; and has received many honours for achievement. Helen Keller greatly furthered the work of the "Foundation of the Blind".\n', 'BULLET::::- In 1925 Helen Keller, through her long-time teacher Anne Sullivan, gave a talk to an audience of 200 at Old Mill School.\n', 'Marcelle Kellermann became a teacher of modern languages in Leeds and at Bingley College of Education in Yorkshire. Her articles on the subject of language teaching included "Two experiments on language teaching in primary schools in Leeds", published by the Nuffield Foundation in 1964. Her monograph in Pergamon Press\'s Language Teaching Methodology series, "The Forgotten Third Skill: Reading a Foreign Language", was published in 1981. She was said to have "pioneered the teaching of French to primary school children".\n', 'According to Anne Sullivan, Helen Keller had developed over sixty home signs long before she was taught to communicate through finger spelling.\n', 'Helen Keller School\n', 'In 1890, Fuller applied the methods she learned and developed from Bell in giving the first speech lessons to Helen Keller.\n']

By incorporating these details, the model can better represent the nuances of Helen Keller's education and the significant role Anne Sullivan played in her ability to communicate, thus reducing the likelihood of model illusions and factual inaccuracies.

question_info.question: Which teacher taught Helen Keller to communicate?
passages:
A message of optimism, of hope, of good cheer, and of loving service was brought to Menomonie Saturday—a message that will linger long with those fortunate enough to have received it. This message came with the visit of Helen Keller and her teacher, Mrs. John Macy, and both had a hand in imparting it Saturday evening to a splendid audience that filled The Memorial. The wonderful girl who has so brilliantly triumphed over the triple afflictions of blindness, dumbness and deafness, gave a talk with her own lips on "Happiness," and it will be remembered always as a piece of inspired teaching by those who heard it.
Sullivan arrived at Keller's house on March 5, 1887, a day Keller would forever remember as "my soul's birthday." Sullivan immediately began to teach Helen to communicate by spelling words into her hand, beginning with "d-o-l-l" for the doll that she had brought Keller as a present. Keller was frustrated, at first, because she did not understand that every object had a word uniquely identifying it. In fact, when Sullivan was trying to teach Keller the word for "mug", Keller became so frustrated she broke the mug. But soon she began imitating Sullivan’s hand gestures. “I did not know that I was spelling a word or even that words existed,” Keller remembered. “I was simply making my fingers go in monkey-like imitation.” 
Determined to communicate with others as conventionally as possible, Keller learned to speak and spent much of her life giving speeches and lectures on aspects of her life. She learned to "hear" people's speech by reading their lips with her hands—her sense of touch had heightened. She became proficient at using braille and reading sign language with her hands as well. Shortly before World War I, with the assistance of the Zoellner Quartet, she determined that by placing her fingertips on a resonant tabletop she could experience music played close by.
Sullivan's curriculum involved a strict schedule with constant introduction of new vocabulary words; however, Sullivan quickly changed her teachings after seeing they did not suit Keller. Instead, she began to teach her vocabulary based on her own interests, by spelling each word out into Keller's palm; within six months this method proved to be working, as Keller had learned 575 words, some multiplication tables, and the Braille system. Sullivan strongly encouraged Helen's parents to send her to the Perkins School, where she could have an appropriate education. Once they agreed to this, Sullivan took Keller to Boston in 1888 and stayed with her there. Sullivan continued to teach her bright protégée, who soon became famous for her remarkable progress. With the help of Anagnos, Keller became a public symbol for the school, helping to increase its funding and donations and making it the most famous and sought-after school for the blind in the country. However, an accusation of plagiarism against Keller greatly upset Sullivan: She left and never returned, but did remain influential to the school. Sullivan remained a close companion to Keller and continued to assist in her education, which ultimately included a degree from Radcliffe College.
Named after Helen Adams Keller (1880–1968), an American author and educator of the blind. From infancy, Keller was without power of speech and was also deaf and blind. With the inestimable assistance of Anne M. Sullivan, Keller learnt to read and to write by Braille; to use a typewriter; and even to speak, and eventually mastered five languages. Upon graduating with honours from Radeliffe, she began to lecture extensively on the education of the blind; and has received many honours for achievement. Helen Keller greatly furthered the work of the "Foundation of the Blind".
BULLET::::- In 1925 Helen Keller, through her long-time teacher Anne Sullivan, gave a talk to an audience of 200 at Old Mill School.
Marcelle Kellermann became a teacher of modern languages in Leeds and at Bingley College of Education in Yorkshire. Her articles on the subject of language teaching included "Two experiments on language teaching in primary schools in Leeds", published by the Nuffield Foundation in 1964. Her monograph in Pergamon Press's Language Teaching Methodology series, "The Forgotten Third Skill: Reading a Foreign Language", was published in 1981. She was said to have "pioneered the teaching of French to primary school children".
According to Anne Sullivan, Helen Keller had developed over sixty home signs long before she was taught to communicate through finger spelling.
Helen Keller School
In 1890, Fuller applied the methods she learned and developed from Bell in giving the first speech lessons to Helen Keller.
